newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX Nikkei futures erase losses, seen supported.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX Nikkei futures erase losses, seen supported.

text.p: SIMEX Nikkei futures bounced back from their early losses to a firm finish on Thursday despite lingering concerns about a growing racketeer scandal surrounding some Japan brokerages.

Dealers said the market looked well-supported on the lower end and was likely to continue trading within its recent ranges because a recent spate of bad news had not pushed it below the psychological 20,000 level, as initially feared.
Nikkei cash and futures markets came under pressure on Wednesday on news of raids on Yamaichi Securities in search of suspected illegal links with racketeers.

The Ministry of Finance's announcement of a raft of punitive measures against Nomura Securities and Dai-ichi Kangyo Bank for their involvement in a racketeer payoff scandal also contributed to the market's early declines.
The lead Nikkei 225 September contract added 125 points to end at 20,345 after falling as low as 20,040 in early trade.
"It was a pretty supportive close. The market may go down when there is any bad news but it should otherwise trade between 20,300 and 20,600," a trader at a U.S. futures house said.
But dealers said the September Nikkei would continue to struggle with resistance above 20,600.
Taiwan stock index futures ended sharply higher as Taipei share prices soared past the 10,000 threshold to close at a seven-year peak on strong buying of electronics and financial sector shares.
The August MSCI contract added 9.1 points to close at 436.4 on active volume of 2,621 lots.
Refco Singapore Pte Ltd said in a daily commentary sentiment on the SIMEX contract remained bullish, with the participation of Taiwanese investors from August 1 expected to boost volumes.
